Iâ€™m with you here. Being sober can be painful and when it comes to handling negative or hurtful emotions with out alcohol, after being reliant on it,  it certainly does feel like hell. Iâ€™m currently 2 months sober so still early days for me but Iâ€™ve been in â€˜recoveryâ€™ from alcoholism for about two years. Thatâ€™s included some strong sober periods followed by relapses, so itâ€™s been a journey to say the least. Iâ€™m at a point now where the best thing Iâ€™ve done in terms of my recovery is to determine what my triggers are whether they be external (places, people, objects, activities or events) or internal triggers (emotions, increased stress, or thoughts). Iâ€™ve spent time on my own and in therapy formulating plans to minimise the risks associated with the triggers. The external triggers can be far easier to avoid or plan for than internal ones.

Practicing distress tolerance and emotional regulation skills (from Dialectical behavioural therapy) is the most effective way Iâ€™ve found to manage painful emotions during sobriety. Iâ€™ve never turned to AA and I donâ€™t think it would work for me but going to group or individual DBT or CBT groups can be really helpful as a means of practicing skills that will help you understand, challenge, and tolerate emotions or thoughts. If the idea of professional therapy doesnâ€™t appeal to you thereâ€™s even some good worksheets or modules you can find online if you search DBT/CBT. Have a look at the CCI website, thereâ€™s some helpful stuff on there. Thatâ€™s just personally whatâ€™s worked for me.

Donâ€™t be too hard on yourself, the journey to recovery is a roller coaster, lapses are normal and so are painful emotions, I hope you can work out a way to process them and good luck in the future. Youâ€™re certainly not alone.

Edit: hereâ€™s just one example of some of the stuff you can try to practice at home to deal with the pain [DBT worksheets](https://www.cci.health.wa.gov.au/Resources/Looking-After-Yourself/Tolerating-Distress)

This in no way has to be your reality. With hard work and persistence youâ€™ll totally get there, it may not come easy but take it day by day and youâ€™ll get there. 

Spend some time to work out exactly what triggered you to drink last night, then work out a list of all your possible triggers and how you can possibly avoid them or respond to them. When I decided I wanted to quit I wrote down every person, place, object, activity, event, emotion and thought that I associated with drinking and worked out a bunch of solutions to minimise the risk associated with each. Tangible triggers like places or objects are far easier to avoid than emotional ones, however practicing distress tolerance or other skills through DBT and CBT can be super helpful. Thereâ€™s lots of info and free worksheets to get yourself familiar with either of these therapies that might help if you donâ€™t want to go to proper therapy for whatever reason. However, if youâ€™re serious about quitting drinking and are struggling to get there on your own having a professional involved will make a huge difference. 

Keep your chin up, lapses are part of the recovery process. This only has to be your reality if you let it.

This is partially because I really do just enjoy doing things for people and I want to help them in anyway I can. I also know in the back of my mind that Iâ€™ve hurt this person in the past and so know that in a way Iâ€™m just constantly trying to make up for things that Iâ€™ve done. It didnâ€™t really occur to me as manipulative until they and I had a conversation where I said I felt unappreciated and wanted to feel a little more effort from them that they brought up I was being manipulative by using my â€˜kindnessâ€™. I donâ€™t know it that clears things up for you but as others have said, most human actions are transactional and itâ€™s pretty normal to have expectations of what peopleâ€™s reactions might be. I guess if itâ€™s troubling you try to focus on the act of being kind itself how that makes you feel and acknowledge that regardless kindness is kindness whether or not you receive a reward or reaction from it. Try to disconnect from the obsessive over the result and donâ€™t be so hard on yourself, youâ€™re only human itâ€™s normal to hope that your efforts are being acknowledged.

I think it was just a maturity thing plus the fact that I had a reputation for lying so people used to question me and I got teased a bit over it. Now that Iâ€™m older I still have a pretty bad habit of lying but not so much over trivial things.

I think my teachers used to say â€˜thatâ€™s not true. Why did you lie about it?â€™ And tell the all the standard stuff like itâ€™s wrong to lie. I donâ€™t remember then punishing me for it or telling me off really but I certainly did stop doing it to a degree by the time I was in high school.

Iâ€™m actually not sure but I think it kinda stemmed from a self esteem thing and just this excessive need to be liked.

Detaching from their FP is going to be extremely difficult. Itâ€™s almost as if that person becomes apart of them and all of their self worth revolves around that relationship. Because people with BPD also have issues with unstable identity it might help if they wrote a list of all the things they enjoy, their values, their goals, and strengths. Recognising that they have self worth and a completely separate identity outside of that person might help them to feel significant enough without that person. You yourself can help them by making them feel loved and appreciated. We crave connection so much and itâ€™ll help if they can get that sense of stability from someone else. The best way to break away from a toxic relationship is to go completely no contact. Otherwise theyâ€™re just going to get them self into a continuous loop of trying to win them back again. Itâ€™ll be very difficult, but recognising that the relationship is abusive and detrimental is the first step. The key is going to be persistence and patience. Thereâ€™s no easy way to break away from your FP regardless how damaging the relationship is. 

My tips would be make sure Your friend has an identity and self worth outside of that relationship, and she can acknowledge that, she deserves better and she has other sources of love and connection, and she does not need that person anymore. Go no contact, delete numbers cut all ties and stay resilient. 

Best of luck to you both.

Iâ€™m very similar Iâ€™ve always lied about unimportant simple things for no reason. I used to make up stories or lie about very insignificant details just because I could and I noticed myself doing it but never knew why and wasnâ€™t particularly bothered by it. As Iâ€™ve gotten older Iâ€™ve definitely gotten better and catch myself out when I do it and make an active effort not to. That being said I also lie about important things to people I care about either out of shame, guilt or manipulation. All of the people that are close to me are aware that I do it so I basically no trust from any of them at this point. 

After a lot of thought I started to think that maybe I lied about insignificant stuff to make myself seem more exciting or fun. I guess in the end it all comes down to wanting to be liked or admired by people. I definitely know I have a problem and most people would probably consider me a compulsive liar but itâ€™s something I have accepted and am trying to change. Building trust back with my loved ones and FP is going to take a lot of work. But know that youâ€™re not alone and itâ€™s something that you can control and change. Acknowledging it is the first step anyway. Hope this helps.

This is 100% a BPD thing. Sounds pretty much like splitting and itâ€™s probably caused by â€˜black and white thinkingâ€™ and our patterns of adoration and demonisation. They either love us or they donâ€™t, theyâ€™re always good to us or theyâ€™re never good to us, we either love them or we hate them. Everything works in absolutes, thereâ€™s never any grey areas or inbetweens. 

Someone who we see as the best person in the world; who we love and adore, can very quickly change into someone whoâ€™s 100% bad and hurtful. If you feel hurt, let down or you perceive abandonment or rejection from this person your BPD brain is probably trying to protect you by immediately casting them as someone you donâ€™t love or care for anyway. As if to make the hurt, loss or rejection (whether itâ€™s real or not) less hurtful to you. Think... â€œI donâ€™t care that he hasnâ€™t messaged me, I hate him anywayâ€, â€œI donâ€™t care that he moved away, heâ€™s nothing to me anywayâ€ etc. 

Splitting sucks, and I for one, am certainly guilty of it. Itâ€™s something thatâ€™s very hard to control and even notice when itâ€™s happening in the moment, but where you can try to remember that things are not always in black and white. If it helps, write a â€˜pros and consâ€™ or â€˜good and badâ€™ list of the good and bad things in your relationship, try to remember why you are together and that itâ€™s normal for relationships to be hard sometimes. If you can try to remind yourself that your relationship is made of light and dark moments (hopefully the majority are light), it might be easier to process how youâ€™re really feeling and even calmly express to your partner what youâ€™re concerned about. 

Hope this helped a little bit and good luck moving forward. Stay strong ğŸ˜Š
